name: Coastal Wetlands
description: Tidal marshes and estuaries rich in fish and small prey, with dense vegetation providing cover.

atmosphere.notes: Cretaceous CO2 levels were approximately 4-6 times modern levels, with oxygen levels similar to today.

flora.name: Ferns
flora.note: Tree ferns and ground ferns dominated wetland ecosystems

flora.name: Cycads
flora.note: Palm-like plants that provided food for herbivores

flora.name: Horsetails
flora.note: Giant Equisetum species lined waterways

flora.name: Early Angiosperms
flora.note: Flowering plants were just beginning to diversify in the Late Cretaceous

hazards.description: Sudden flooding from tidal changes or storms
Natural asphalt seeps creating deadly traps

scientificFacts: Coastal wetlands supported rich biodiversity with fish, invertebrates, and small vertebrates providing abundant prey.
The Western Interior Seaway divided North America, creating extensive coastal environments.
Many dinosaur species were adapted to semi-aquatic lifestyles in these environments.

name: Fern Prairies
description: Open expanses of low-growing ferns and cycads with scattered conifer stands, home to great herds.

atmosphere.notes: Slightly elevated oxygen in some Mesozoic periods may have supported larger insect sizes.

flora.name: Ground Ferns
flora.note: Low-growing fern species covered open ground

flora.name: Bennettitales
flora.note: Cycad-like plants with flower-like reproductive structures

flora.name: Araucaria
flora.note: Monkey puzzle trees provided shelter and food

flora.name: Early Grasses
flora.note: Primitive grasses were just evolving in the Late Cretaceous

hazards.description: Extended dry periods stress herbivore populations
Large herds passing through can trample smaller creatures

scientificFacts: Before the evolution of grasses, ferns and cycads dominated open environments.
Large herbivore herds migrated seasonally following vegetation patterns.
Pack hunting theropods may have targeted the edges of migrating herds.

name: Volcanic Highlands
description: Elevated terrain shaped by volcanic activity, with ash-enriched soil supporting unique flora.

atmosphere.notes: Volcanic emissions increased local CO2 and sulfur compounds, affecting local climate.

flora.name: Pioneer Ferns
flora.note: Hardy ferns colonized volcanic soils first

flora.name: Ginkgoes
flora.note: Living fossils that tolerated harsh conditions

flora.name: Conifers
flora.note: Adapted to nutrient-poor volcanic soils

hazards.description: Explosive volcanic activity threatens all life

scientificFacts: Volcanic activity was common throughout the Mesozoic, with the Deccan Traps erupting near the K-Pg extinction.
Volcanic soils are rich in nutrients once weathered, supporting unique plant communities.
Some dinosaurs may have exploited volcanic thermal areas for nesting, similar to modern megapodes.

name: Tar Pits
description: Deadly pools of natural asphalt that trap the unwary, creating fossil bonanzas for future scientists.

atmosphere.notes: Methane and petroleum vapors rise from tar seeps, creating localized atmospheric anomalies.

flora.name: Drought-resistant Ferns
flora.note: Only the hardiest plants survive near tar seeps

flora.name: Scrub Conifers
flora.note: Stunted trees growing away from tar deposits

hazards.description: Viscous tar can trap any creature that steps in it
Predators become trapped trying to reach stuck prey

scientificFacts: Tar pits like La Brea preserve exceptional fossils because trapped animals attracted predators who also became stuck.
The predator-to-prey ratio in tar pit fossils is abnormally high, reflecting this trap dynamic.
Asphalt preserves bone exceptionally well, providing detailed anatomical information.

name: Conifer Forest
description: Towering Araucaria and redwood-like conifers create a shadowy understory rich with prey.

atmosphere.notes: Dense vegetation created localized oxygen-rich microclimates.

flora.name: Araucaria
flora.note: Massive monkey puzzle trees dominated the canopy

flora.name: Tree Ferns
flora.note: Tall ferns filled the middle story

flora.name: Cycads
flora.note: Understory cycads provided herbivore food

flora.name: Mosses
flora.note: Ground cover and epiphytes on tree trunks

hazards.description: Falling timber can crush the unwary
Lightning strikes can ignite devastating fires
Dense vegetation provides cover for predators

scientificFacts: Mesozoic forests were dominated by conifers and ferns, with flowering plants rare until the Late Cretaceous.
Forest fires were common and may have driven evolution of fire-resistant plant adaptations.
Many small mammals and early birds lived in forest canopies, mostly out of reach of large dinosaurs.

name: Western Interior Seaway
description: The shallow warm sea that divided North America, home to marine reptiles and pterosaurs.

atmosphere.notes: Ocean currents and sea spray influenced local atmospheric conditions.

flora.name: Coastal Ferns
flora.note: Salt-tolerant ferns lined the shoreline

flora.name: Mangrove-like Plants
flora.note: Ancient equivalents of mangroves stabilized coasts

flora.name: Seaweed
flora.note: Massive kelp-like forests in shallow waters

hazards.description: Strong currents pull swimmers into deep water
Apex marine predators patrol the waters

scientificFacts: The Western Interior Seaway covered much of central North America from the Gulf of Mexico to the Arctic Ocean.
Marine reptiles like mosasaurs were apex predators, occupying ecological niches similar to modern orcas.
The seaway supported rich ecosystems including ammonites, fish, and marine reptiles.
